title: 111_hr6345
content: "The Personal Exemption Fairness Act of 2010 may be cited as the Act. It includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in personal exemptions." The Personal Exemption Fairness Act of 2010, also known as the Act, introduces regional cost-of-living adjustments in personal exemptions. Subsection (d) of section 151 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include an area cost-of-living adjustment based on the taxpayer's primary place of abode. The applicable multiplier for the taxable year is determined by the statistical area where the taxpayer resides. The Personal Exemption Fairness Act of 2010 introduces regional cost-of-living adjustments in personal exemptions. An applicable multiplier is prescribed for each statistical area of the United States for taxable years. The multiplier is based on the cost-of-living differential for the calendar year in the taxpayer's area of residence. The Personal Exemption Fairness Act of 2010 introduces cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in the United States for taxable years. The Secretary of Labor determines the cost-of-living for each area annually. The Secretary of Labor annually determines and publishes a cost-of-living index for each statistical area based on average market prices for the area for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of the calendar year. The Secretary of Labor determines the Consumer Price Index for Urban Consumers based on market prices. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. Transition rule: The date for prescribing applicable multipliers for taxable years beginning in calendar year 2011 will be 1 year after the enactment of this Act, despite the changes in the Internal Revenue Code.
